title: 105_hr3157
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teachers in the Classroom Act". Congress finds that elementary and secondary school enrollment is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The trend of increasing enrollment is projected to continue for the next decade, particularly in high poverty urban and rural areas and states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to expand to accommodate the growing number of students. The unprecedented increase in student enrollment, projected to rise by over 13 percent, will impact high poverty urban and rural areas, as well as states with rapid population growth. To keep up with the growing number of students, schools will need to hire 150,000 additional teachers in the next decade. Research from Project STAR in Tennessee shows that students in smaller classes in the early grades learn more and maintain an academic advantage even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. Research suggests that students in smaller classes in the early grades learn more and maintain an academic advantage even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. Adding students to a classroom diminishes learning for the rest of the class. It is important to adequately educate and prepare America's children for the future. Congress needs to provide resources for hiring new teachers without increasing the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. Congress needs to fund positions for teachers without adding to the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt, and provide resources to keep pace with growing enrollment and reduce classroom sizes. The grant program is established to fund positions for teachers without increasing the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt, and to provide resources for growing enrollment and reducing classroom sizes. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors for hiring teachers to reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must apply to receive the grant, and local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for the received funds. Local educational agencies must meet certain criteria to be eligible for a grant from the Governor, including establishing a trust fund for received payments, using funds to hire new teachers within 2 years, following accounting practices set by the Governor, and ensuring a net gain in teachers or instructional staff. The agency must adhere to accounting practices set by the Governor, allow State access to financial records, increase the number of teachers, review personnel performance annually, limit employment to one year, repay unused funds within 27 months, and use funds only for supplementation. The agency must adhere to accounting practices, allow State access to financial records, increase teachers, review personnel annually, limit employment to one year, repay unused funds within 27 months, use funds for supplementation, and apply for funding annually. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State receives funds based on the number of children aged 5-17. Unused funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) after 60 days of notice. The agency must increase teachers or qualified personnel to continue receiving funds. SEC. 6. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies based on the need to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must evaluate and report on the funds used by the agencies annually and can use up to 2 percent of the funds for administrative costs. Additionally, Governors can use funds for innovative teaching programs. The Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies to alleviate overcrowded classes. They can use up to 2 percent of the funds for administrative costs and up to 10 percent for innovative teaching programs. The Secretary of Education will report findings annually to relevant committees. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with Governors, must report annually to relevant committees on the effectiveness of programs assisted under the Act and provide recommendations for program continuity. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not provide tenure to personnel hired under it. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. Defines "local educational agency," "State," and "Secretary." SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act are as follows: $500,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $2,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, and $2,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2003.
